Posts.Content: blondedoris wrote: Hey everyone Have been confirmed with mets to neck lymph node, bone and suspected lung mets. I've been given tablet form chemo (which for me is better than the infusions) so am waiting to see how this pans out. They're not sure what the spots in the lung really are, but given that they weren't there 2 years ago on the previous scan they're being assumed as malignant. Had horrendous pain in my shins and was expecting that to be bone mets - turned out that was the femara but there is a met on my skull...go figure. How long do they wait when you start a new regimen to scan again and see if it's worked or not? I know this is only day 2 of treatment but patience has never been my strong point! Hugs, Colette Who Dares Gins... Dx 9/9/2009, IDC, Left, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/10 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (FISH) Surgery 10/14/2009 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Surgery 11/24/2009 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 12/22/2009 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Ellence (epirubicin), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 5/17/2010 Whole-breast: Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 5/29/2010 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Surgery 1/30/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Hormonal Therapy 2/21/2012 Femara (letrozole) Surgery 6/20/2012 Prophylactic mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Surgery 11/8/2012 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Dx 12/5/2014, IDC, Left, 3cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/lungs/other, Grade 3, 1/10 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- (FISH) Hormonal Therapy 12/16/2014 Aromasin (exemestane) Chemotherapy 1/11/2015 Navelbine (vinorelbine), Xeloda (capecitabine) Radiation Therapy 2/16/2015 Bone Chemotherapy 8/6/2015 Taxol (paclitaxel) Hormonal Therapy 3/7/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole) Radiation Therapy 4/25/2016 External: Bone Chemotherapy 10/11/2016 Halaven (eribulin) Dx 5/8/2017, IDC, Left, Stage IV, metastasized to brain/bone/lungs, Grade 3, 1/10 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 03:31AM blondedoris wrote: Heyas I had 3 x FEC followed by 3 x Taxotere. I was given anti-nausea meds to take on the day (Emend) and then some to take for the next couple of days after the infusions. Felt nauseous but no barfing, so that was good. I lost my hair about 12 days after the first treatment, but got some brilliant hats from www.cjhats.com (do have a wig but it makes me feel more like a cancer patient than the hats do...don't know why, I'm just a bit odd like that!). There's a brilliant thread on Tips for Chemo - have a read through that. Chemo sucks, but it was do-able, and given the reduction in % chance of recurrance I think it was worth it. Hang in there sweetie - it can feel like a long haul but you can do this xxxx

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2015 07:46AM blondedoris wrote: Hey Sam Stop googling!! Seriously. You'll do your head in. Remember that 80% of lumps are benign, and you have a referral to go to so you have a plan (mammogram and ultrasound?) There's plenty of support on here in the meantime but try to breathe - your dr has booked you the scans, so it's just the wait in between (which I know is hard and easier said than done, but otherwise you're going to waste a whole lot of energy and exhaust yourself). Can you sort something out as a treat in the meanwhile to take your mind off it? Something like a massage, or manicure, or rent some films that you've been meaning to watch? I find distraction is a good coping technique. All the best sweetie Colette

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2015 08:57AM blondedoris wrote: Heyas sorry to hear about your lung met. I found out earlier this month I have 3 spots in my lung (adds up to about 1cm in total) and am on vinorelbine (navelbine in a tablet) and xeloda. It's not been too bad as far as chemo goes; 2 weeks on and one week off and everything has been do-able at the moment. The PET scan itself was fine; just a little strange as the isotope injection was poked through a hole in the wall, (had a cannula in my arm which he nurse attached the tube to, and then started the infusion from next door) and I got to sit there alone in the little room for about an hour with the lights dimmed waiting for it to take. The scan itself only took 20 minutes. Waiting is always the hardest part...we're all here waiting with you x

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2016 01:24AM blondedoris wrote: Heya I was on Dexamethasone (same as decahedron) for a couple of months - it's a vile drug but it's meant to be one of the best for preventing brain swelling. I was put on it whilst I had radiation to the skull for bone lesions. When cutting back on the drug, it needs to be done slowly - I ended up reducing the dose by 0.5mg a week. Whilst coming off the drug, I experienced nausea, insomnia, dizziness, fatigue and cramps. If the symptoms get too severe, the advice was to increase the dose again. It took about six weeks after the last dose for the symptoms to abate, and it also leaves your immune system more vulnerable to infections (my GP has told me that can last for around 3 months after the last dose). It's a complicated medication - your poor mum really needs to talk to her doctor about coming off and what she's experiencing. x
